Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 06:29 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 31 mins The 11 best places to live in Britain to suit you and your family By Sophie Jamieson | Telegraph – 29 minutes ago 15.41 0.00 
Willing to up sticks to find your ideal home? Looking for affordable house prices or rents? Here’s where you should be going 
Who wants to live in London these days? Overcrowded, overpriced and overhyped , the mass exodus away from the capital continues. 
With 82pc of Brits now living in towns and cities, there has never been more choice of urban property available, both to rent and to buy. 
“Each town town and city is different, with a unique sense of character and place, each attracting a different type of resident,” Jennet Siebrits, Head of Residential Research at CRBE writes in a new report on towns and cities. 
Ready to relocate to find your perfect location? These towns and cities selected by the Telegraph and CBRE are the pick of the bunch. 
Hover over the map to find out more about each city 
= 1. The alternative capital - Cardiff = 
Current population: 324,800 Average age: 36.5 Average house price: £194,867 Average rent for a two bed property: £698 
Want to live in a capital city where you can afford both to pay the rent and enjoy the nightlife? Cardiff is the place for you. 
Nearly a quarter of the population are aged between 20 and 34 and a large independent TV production industry means you will find a wealth of trendy media types hanging around Cardiff Bay, the largest waterfront development in Europe. 
Locals enjoy higher salaries than the rest of Wales with much lower rent than London. It’s no wonder the city’s population is expected to grow by almost a fifth in the next five years. 
A luxurious one bedroom apartment in this building in Cardiff Bay is available for £700 a month, much cheaper than the equivalent in London (Rightmove (LSE: RMV.L - news ) ) 
= 2. Home to high flyers with deep pockets - Leeds = 
Current population: 783,698 Average age: 37.6 Average house price: £171,225 Average rent: £689 
Dubbed the Knightsbridge of the North, there are plenty of people in Leeds who can afford to splash the cash in the city’s beautiful Victorian arcades or the sparkling new Trinity (HKSE: 0891-OL.HK - news ) shopping centre. 
Leeds now has the second largest economy in the UK and one of the biggest financial and legal centres outside of London, employing 1.3m people, making the West Yorkshire city an excellent choice for anyone seeking a strong jobs market in a vibrant, fashionable city. 
King Edward Street in the Victoria Quarter, Leeds (Alamy) 
= 3. The place to blow a nest egg - Oxford = 
Current population: 150,749 Average age: 34.3 Average house price: £431,143 Average rent: £1,459 
Phenomenal demand for property, driven up by London commuters and restrictive planning laws preventing greenbelt development to fulfil housing needs, has made Oxford the most unaffordable place to live in the country. Average house prices are 16.1 times the local average annual income. 
But if you do have enough in the coffers to buy an Oxford home, you won’t live to regret it. Average house prices grew by a huge 55pc over the last decade and the famous university city is unlikely to lose its appeal. 
This stunning seven bedroom Victorian house in North Oxford is on the market with Savills (Other OTC: SVLPF - news ) with a guide price of £3.5m (Savills) 
= 4. The new metropolis - Aberdeen = 
Current population: 217,120 Average age: 38.7 Average house price: £228,864 Average rent: £1,059 
With a diverse and moneyed population thanks to the local oil industry, Aberdeen is ideal if you are looking for somewhere that is not up and coming but has already 'up and come.' 
With its striking granite buildings that glint in the sun, views of the sea and 45 parks and gardens, Aberdeen is certainly a scenic place to live. Not just a pretty face, the north east Scottish city boasts a reputation as a specialist energy skills hub and world centre for undersea petroleum technology. 
Enjoy the views of Aberdeen Harbour (Alamy) 
= 5. The best place for first time buyers - Leicester = 
Current population: 334,501 Average age: 34.8 Average house price: £176,182 Average rent: £604 
Leicester has the lowest rents of any of the cities on this list, at just £604 for an average two bedroom home. Properties are also 30pc lower on average than the country as a whole, at £176,182, making it an attractive prospect for first time buyers. 
Lower prices do not mean you compromise on culture and lifestyle - Leicester is one of the oldest cities in England and rich in history. If it’s good enough for Richard III, it’s good enough for us. 
A budget of only £115,000 would buy you this characterful two bedroom house in Leicester (eMoov) 
= 6. The Peter Pan city - Manchester = 
Current population: 514,513 Average age: 33.2 Average house price: £150,021 Average rent: £772 
It really is the city that does not grow up. Of all the cities profiled by CRBE, Manchester has the highest proportion of 20-34 year-olds. 
The ‘Northern Capital’ and epitome of urban cool has four universities and the second highest number of students in the UK, many of whom choose to stay after graduation and enjoy Manchester’s cosmopolitan lifestyle. 
Manchester Town Hall (Alamy) 
= 7. Best for stability seekers - Warwick = 
Current population: 140,617 Average age: 39.7 Average house price: £291,683 Average rent: £769 
The Shakespearean Midlands town of Warwick is great for seekers of job security and prosperity. Unemployment here is only 3pc and 68pc of people own their own home. 
That paycheck will also provide you with a high standard of living. Warwick is an affluent area with high average wages and upmarket leisure activities including literary and folk festivals. 
The sort of family home on offer in Wellesbourne, near Warwick - a four bedroom detached house for £335,000 (eMoov) 
= 8. The city that won’t stand still - Birmingham = 
Current population: 1,103,418 Average age: 35.3 Average house price: £156,581 Average rent: £754 
A city heaving with character and history at every corner, Birmingham refuses to stagnate, with more schemes granted planning permission in the last two years than any other location on our list. Here, 8pc of property sales are new build homes. 
Innovation is at the heart of what Birmingham is all about, with its five universities and opinion-splitting vast new public library. Expect Birmingham to keep flourishing - HSBC is set to relocate its retail banking headquarters here and many other companies will surely follow especially after the rail service High Speed 2 arrives in town. 
The Selfridges building in the Bull Ring shopping centre, Birmingham (Alamy) 
= 9. The place to grow old in - Chester = 
Current population: 104,594 Average age: 41.3 Average house price: £196,554 Average rent: £708 
Once you move to Chester, you will never want to leave. That might explain why Chester has the highest average age of any of the places studied by CRBE, 41.3. 
With Roman ruins, well-preserved town walls and restored medieval buildings, you could not ask for a more attractive town. Equally attractive is Chester’s booming tourist economy, valued at £1.78bn a year. 
The old streets of Chester (Alamy) 
= 10. Best for young renters - Glasgow = 
Current population: 592,820 Average age: 38 Average house price: £134,466 Average rent: £684 
Cheaper, cooler and more innovative than Edinburgh, Glasgow is the smart choice for young renters looking to get the most out of their budgets. 
Glasgow does not stint on style, with beautiful buildings designed by renowned architect Rennie Mackintosh, and a buzzing hipster vibe to rival London’s Shoreditch in the West End. 
For the same price as a box room in outer London, you could share this incredible two bedroom Glasgow apartment (Rightmove) 
= 11. The cultural capital - Bath = 
Current population: 180,124 Average age: 40.3 Average house price: £368,108 Average rent: £1,040 
If you have ever fancied living in a Unesco World Heritage site, Bath is the place for you. Georgian architecture meets Roman baths and rolling countryside in this jewel of the southwest. 
If you can put up with rubbing shoulders with tourists retracing the steps of Jane Austen, you will enjoy house price growth above the national average and an increasingly varied range of employment opportunities, as software, publishing and service-oriented industries all bed down in the city. 
Somerset Place, a Georgian crescent in Bath
